positive.review: Honestly, this game is truly underrated. That 2009‚Äì2016 era of FPS games was something special, and coming back to Titanfall 2 just reminds me how unmatched it really was. The combat is slick and incredibly fluid, movement just feels great even if a little floaty. I‚Äôm still not the biggest fan of some of the guns (a few lean a bit too hard into sci fi gimmick territory for me with a few interesting ones I wont lie), but the moment to moment gameplay more than makes up for it. The story isn‚Äôt the most original premise you‚Äôll ever see, but it never tries to be anything it isn‚Äôt. It‚Äôs confident, tight, and surprisingly heartfelt. The banter with BT hits that perfect balance of dry humour, warmth, and weight a nice emotional break from the game‚Äôs overall darker tone. It's genuinely one of the better buddy dynamic narratives in shooters. And the level design? Honestly incredible. There are moments here that feel like master class set pieces taking advantage of unique mechanics in ways that are memorable without feeling like gimmicks. Levels like that one (you know the one) are still talked about for a reason, and even outside the standout moments, the campaign‚Äôs pacing and creativity keep things constantly engaging. It's got some decent performances by its voice actors which is always appreciated. It‚Äôs short, punchy, and doesn‚Äôt waste your time a rare thing now. Titanfall 2 really deserved better support and recognition at launch, because even today it stands toe to toe with the best shooters ever made.

EA doesn't deserve Titanfall.

This is one of the most beloved FPS games for a reason. The campaign is fantastic, the movement has an incredibly high skill ceiling, the guns are awesome, Titan combat is really fleshed out and integrates amazingly into the game's singleplayer and multiplayer, there's not really any microtransactions, and there's no skill-based matchmaking. You start out sucking at the game, and as you get better, you really [i]feel[/i] your improvement as you begin to stand out against the other players in the lobby. It's very gratifying and refreshing compared to the dozens of modern FPS games where you are basically guaranteed to have a 50% winrate no matter how good you are due to their ELO systems. 

The overwhelming community love and support for this game that has grown even past the game's heyday is something that is extremely undervalued by soulless megacorp Electronic Arts. I guess it's just less risky and probably more profitable to continue to milk Apex Legends until the Titanfall franchise fades into irrelevance.

I'm writing this review some 9 years after Titanfall 2's release, and yet it remains one of the best looking and best playing single player First Person Shooters ever made. It's genuinely remarkable how good this still looks, and it does so whilst running at very high frame rates on pretty much anything. Stutterstruggle is not an issue with Titanfall 2, as it runs on Valve's Source Engine, not Unreal. Zero stutters, zero hitches, just super fluid frame rates. Amazing what the combination of great art and a great engine can achieve, something we don't see much of anymore.

The game also plays amazingly well. It has a perfect blend of high speed traversal with double jumps, wall running etc, with a big variety of unique sci-fi weaponry which all feel satisfying to use. They all sound great too, in fact the sound in general is top tier with a great cinematic soundtrack and a very densely layered sound mix.

The campaign itself is also flat out great. The story is fine but the real heart of the story is the friendship between the main character and the mech. Dialogue is nicely done, just enough banter without ever getting annoying.

It's too bad we never got a sequel to this, although it would probably have been on Unreal and looked and ran far worse than this. Still we'll always have Titanfall 2, which I expect will remain one an FPS high point for many years to come.

Don't skip this one just because it's a few years old, it's still a phenomenal game from start to finish.

Titanfall 2 Underrated King of Movement and Mech Mayhem

Titanfall 2 isn‚Äôt just a shooter ‚Äî it‚Äôs a full-blown adrenaline machine that refuses to slow down. From the second you wall-run into a slide, double-jump over a grenade, and drop a Titan from orbit like it‚Äôs your own personal meteor strike, you realize this game plays in a league of its own.

The combat is fast, fluid, and absurdly satisfying. Gunplay feels crisp, every weapon has personality, and the game somehow balances acrobatic pilots with gigantic metal death machines without breaking a sweat. One moment you‚Äôre zipping across rooftops like cyber-parkour royalty, and the next you‚Äôre stomping around in a Titan, turning enemies into glowing confetti.

And let‚Äôs talk mobility ‚Äî because wow. Titanfall 2 makes movement feel like a superpower. Wall-running, grappling, sliding‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs so smooth that every other FPS feels a little sluggish afterward. Once you get the rhythm, it‚Äôs like the game plugs directly into your brain.

Then there‚Äôs the multiplayer ‚Äî yes, it's still alive, and yes, it‚Äôs still ridiculously addictive. Every match feels like a highlight reel waiting to happen. Even years later, the community keeps the game humming, and jumping into a lobby still feels like meeting old friends who all learned how to sprint on walls.

Titanfall 2 is a modern FPS classic ‚Äî overlooked, underappreciated, but endlessly fun. Whether you're dropping Titans, styling on enemies with acrobatics, or just living out your mech-pilot fantasy, this game delivers pure, high-octane joy from start to finish.

Rating 4.5/5

Titanfall 2 is fascinating. 

An interesting concept, a short but solid campaign, and mechs. What's not to love right?

It must simply be one of those games that suffers from how overhyped it is. Saying it's overrated is a death sentence in the eyes of the remaining 1000 players, but it's deeper than that. Believing the movement isn't great simply MUST be contrarian and thinking the gameplay loop isn't engaging is antagonistic. It's remarkable loyalty shared clearly far and wide with 90k Overwhelmingly Positive reviews. 

And yet, for all the accolades and praise that people will throw its way, only 1000 are willing to actually play. The steadfast 1000 will point toward a botched launch or abandonment from the publishers, but the reality is far simpler. 

Titanfall simply isn't as good as they've convinced themselves.

Jesus I wasn't ready for this, but I hated coming back to this game...

Despite the low time listed I played this a lot when I still had my old EA account. I remember having a good enough time coming back to the campaign every so often, but this go around? Ugh...

The campaign's gameplay is painfully "gamey." I know, that sounds like a nothing statement, but the novelty of stompy mech game clearly whitewashed much of my memory. 2025 me is just not okay with the amount of sterile "this is a video game" type moments.

Here is obligatory too literal robot humor. Ha, funny. Here is the obligatory time travel level. Woo, go 2016. Here's the overblown "mwa ha ha, we so EEE-Vile" villains, complete with corporate mercenaries protecting the toxic waste facilities of their actual death chamber factory. I can't believe I can accurately write that statement, it's like the game was a parody of itself...

The gunplay is...adequate, but it's not really inventive. Going back, there aren't really fun guns. Just, the guns every game had at the time. Sure, they might have sci-fi skins, but here's the revolver! It revolvers. Here's the machine gun! It go dudda-dudda-dudda. There are a few neat guns, but nothing beats the carbine for me...in a setting with big, stompy mech battles...

The platforming is...functional? After playing Jedi Survivor, it's clear that Respawn is competent at hiding the seams of their platforming segments, but only just. What I mean is that...it's clear that this part is a ramp and it acts like ramps do. Here is the blatant roadblock to movement that must be double-jumped or wall-ran. It's functional, is what I'm saying. Not as blatant as, I don't know, Star Wars Outlaws going "this is a yellow spot, so you can climb it" type stuff, but not by enough to wow me.

The mech battles are fine, but again, not really excellent. It's just the Gears-core chunky boi shooter with a mech theme on it, almost completely separate from the too-mobile for its own good pilot combat. I never had a moment where I went...oh! That mech is hunkered down, let me get out and rodeo it as my pilot. I just shot it with my mech til it died. I never pined for my mech in a shootout. Any challenge was just "oh! I died...darn. What got me? Some bull? Cool."

I really like BT (the bot) and Cooper (the guy) and their interactions, but that's about all that really stuck with me after all of this time. The stuff that should be core memories of my time with the game just slide off of my neurons.

That's all the campaign. The multiplayer has been anemic since I started playing years ago, so I can't say much about it, other than that Respawn never figured out how to make pilots work as bots, so that's probably why they don't exist. In hindsight, that was probably why Titanfall 1 was multiplayer only, too.

I don't hate the game. I'm not mad at it, but this has aged poorly for me and I have requested a refund, because I have zero interest in playing the game ever again. That doesn't take my fond memories of my time away from me or anything. I can still fondly recall staying up to beat the campaign when it first came out, even as I can appreciate that the game isn't as good as I remember.

If you don't have rose-tinted goggles for this, you can skip it. There's clearly a reason they never made a Titanfall 3 and it had nothing to do with a lack of interest for one.

Not my thing. And I think there are 3 reasons for that:

1. The plot hook was not strong enough for me. Not like I expected something extraordinary or anything, but... When that captain died, it was extremely forced and almost nonsensical. Neither he, nor the Titan had any observable substantial damage. Aside from missing batteries, which also made little sense.

2. The shooting felt weird. Almost weightless, I guess, like there was no real impact force behind the bullets. Which is strange, because visually the enemies were exploding into pieces. It also sounded muffled, and playing with in-game and even system settings did not seem to change that. Both of these issues seemed to persists for multiple weapons, and even inside the Titan.

3. Visuals... Hey, it looks amazing, I would not even guess it's from 2016, even if I did not know that. Runs at around 60 with periodic dips on ultra settings (one of the early cutscenes dipped to 12FPS somehow), even on 7900XTX. But problem is that it's just too detailed for my brain. I had similar issue with some multiplayer maps in F.E.A.R. especially some "tropical" one or whatever. So many little details, so many happening, and everything is so sharp, that it's borderline sensory overload for me, resulting in a very tiring experience of just trying to focus on something. Especially, if I am also to shoot while wall-running.

While plot may get better at a later point, I doubt that the other 2 points will change, so I just got my Steam cards and removed the game. Good that I got it only for 3 euros.
